Departing from his custom, he wrote this speech in the form of Oratio Recta3 and as there was certainly no shorthand writer present when Critognatus was speaking, the words were of course Caesar’s own. But we may reasonably suppose that he was informed of the drift of Critognatus’s arguments by some one who had listened to them—perhaps by Vercinge torix himself—for he made at least 60,000 prisoners after the fall of Alesia.¹
